div.p: Title: The “window mirror:” A new model of the patient-physician relationship

p.hi: : Stephen Buetow is Senior Research Fellow and Director of Research, Department of General Practice and Primary Health Care, University of Auckland. Glyn Elwyn is Professor of Primary Care Medicine at Cardiff University.

div.p: Competing interests: None declared.

Correspondence: Dr. S. Buetow, Department of General Practice and Primary Health Care, University of Auckland, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, New Zealand;
telephone +64-9-373-7599, extension 86241; email: s.buetow@auckland.ac.nz
Word count: 2,462

Current, idealised models of the patient-doctor relationship focus solely on the care needs and interests of the patient (see Table 1). Physician needs are typically perceived as secondary in that they are not deliberately motivated by physician self‑regard or by patient regard for the physician. However, this contravenes the ethical principle of taking into equal consideration all relevant and like interests in the patient‑physician relationship. This paper explains the relevance of this principle; how it is challenged by decentering physician interests in the moral calculus of the patient‑physician relationship; and why this corollary of the existing models demands not less attention to patients but rather a more egalitarian model that sharpens the focus on both parties in the patient‑physician relationship. We will present such a model that illuminates and aids responsiveness to unmet interests of patients and physicians; at least where their interaction develops into a continuing relationship whose depth and breadth of context produce preconditions for care, as in family medicine ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Starfield</Author><Year>1996</Year><RecNum>1417</RecNum><record><rec-number>1417</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Starfield, B.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Primary care: Balancing health needs, services and technology</title></titles><dates><year>1996</year></dates><pub-location>New York</pub-location><publisher>Oxford University Press</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[1][1].

Before discussing the principle of equal consideration of equal interests in care, we need to define what we mean by “care.” For us, this concept does not denote the provision of all medical services, as its often loose usage implies. It is, instead, “an activity defining a connectedness with and respectful attention to the concrete needs of others and self” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Buetow</Author><Year>2005</Year><RecNum>2271</RecNum><record><rec-number>2271</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Buetow, S</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>To care is to coprovide</title><secondary-title>Ann Fam Med</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Ann Fam Med</full-title></periodical><pages>553-555</pages><volume>3</volume><dates><year>2005</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[2][2]. It also involves an “intersubjective human process” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Watson</Author><Year>1989</Year><RecNum>2511</RecNum><record><rec-number>2511</rec-number><ref-type name="Book Section">5</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Watson, J</author></authors><secondary-authors><author>Riehl-Sisca, J</author></secondary-authors></contributors><titles><title>Watson's philosophy and theory of human caring in nursing</title><secondary-title>Conceptual Models for Nursing Practice</secondary-title></titles><pages>219-36</pages><edition>3rd</edition><dates><year>1989</year></dates><pub-location>Norwalk</pub-location><publisher>Appleton and Lange</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[3][3], a socially constituted co-creation of shared, symbolic meaning that is an expressive and instrumental function of human behavior. Care therefore goes beyond the reciprocation occasioned by payment for services or even the benefit that accrues from being entrusted with human lives; it precludes a one‑sided relationship in which “the patient remains the true focus” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Laine</Author><Year>1996</Year><RecNum>848</RecNum><record><rec-number>848</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Laine, C.</author><author>F. Davidoff</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Patient-centred medicine. A professional evolution</title><secondary-title>JAMA</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Journal of the American Medical Association</full-title><abbr-1>JAMA</abbr-1></periodical><pages>152-5</pages><volume>275</volume><number>2</number><dates><year>1996</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[4][4]. Although patients and physicians have some different interests that require different consideration, these parties also share certain equal interests in the care defining their relationship. These equal interests include respect and not “suffering” stress needlessly, as through neglect of “self.”

Equal consideration of equal interests in care has two moral justifications, although the second is more usually put forward. First, it is based on the right – and, within the limits of what is reasonable in individual circumstances – the responsibility of physicians and patients to care and be cared about. This right and responsibility exist on the basis of shared “common sense” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Beauchamp</Author><Year>2001</Year><RecNum>485</RecNum><record><rec-number>485</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Beauchamp, T.L.</author><author>J.F. Childress</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Principles of Biomedical Ethics</title></titles><edition>5th </edition><dates><year>2001</year></dates><pub-location>Oxford</pub-location><publisher>Oxford University Press</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[5][5], common moral intuitions ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Jonsen</Author><Year>1988</Year><RecNum>1802</RecNum><record><rec-number>1802</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Jonsen, AR</author><author>Toulmin, S</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The Abuse of Casuistry: A History of Moral Reasoning</title></titles><dates><year>1988</year></dates><pub-location>Berkeley</pub-location><publisher>University of California Press</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[6][6] or an “overlapping moral consensus” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Rawls</Author><Year>1999</Year><RecNum>2525</RecNum><record><rec-number>2525</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Rawls, J</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The Law of Peoples; with, The Idea of Public Reason Revisited</title></titles><dates><year>1999</year></dates><pub-location>Cambridge, Massachusetts</pub-location><publisher>Harvard University Press</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[7][7] that patients and physicians have equal inherent moral value. This moral value exists because patients and physicians are moral agents (and sentient beings). Their common morality is in our view external to medicine because the “ends of any practice such as medicine must come … from the basic ends or purposes of … living” whose determination requires philosophical and religious reflection ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Veatch</Author><Year>2001</Year><RecNum>2212</RecNum><record><rec-number>2212</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Veatch, R</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The impossibility of a morality internal to medicine</title><secondary-title>Journal of Medicine and Philosophy</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Journal of Medicine and Philosophy</full-title></periodical><pages>621-42</pages><volume>26</volume><dates><year>2001</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[8][8]. Of course, it is always necessary to apply this common morality in context; for example, patients have reduced power and may be further weakened by anxiety, fear and sickness; physicians occupy roles with vested power. A result can be unequal capacities but each party has, and can serve in its own way, a common interest in care.

The second justification draws on the consequences of actions that consider, or not, equal interests. Not caring about physicians undermines respect for them, leaving their professional identity shaken; their morale, low ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Flagler</Author><Year>1999</Year><RecNum>1222</RecNum><record><rec-number>1222</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Flagler, E.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>On medicine, meaning and morale</title><secondary-title>Ann R Coll Physicians Surg Can</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Ann R Coll Physicians Surg Can</full-title></periodical><pages>420-1</pages><volume>32</volume><dates><year>1999</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[9][9]. Altruistic and frequently overworked, many physicians experience burnout ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Figley</Author><Year>1995</Year><RecNum>2505</RecNum><record><rec-number>2505</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Figley, CR.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Compassion Fatigue</title></titles><dates><year>1995</year></dates><pub-location>New York</pub-location><publisher>Brunner/Mazel</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[10][10]. They suffer, and their patients suffer the fallout. Patients’ interests are integrally connected to what also serves physician interests well. If physicians neglect, or do not care about, themselves, as well as their patients, and if patients do not care about themselves and their physicians, neither party is in the best position, for example, to care about the patient and improve, maintain or restore the health of the patient.

In turn, considering equally the equal interests of patients and physicians protects their mutual well‑being in patient‑physician relationships. It recognizes and cultivates the synergies described above, for example by promoting in concrete terms the development of integrated patient-physician agreements. These “bridge” the full interests of the patient and physician ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Pruitt</Author><Year>1981</Year><RecNum>833</RecNum><record><rec-number>833</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Pruitt, D.G.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Negotiation Behaviour</title></titles><dates><year>1981</year></dates><pub-location>New York</pub-location><publisher>Academic Press</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[11][11] – rather than require compromise – for the benefit of both. A clinical example of bridging is agreeing to a trial of labor for an expectant mother who favors vaginal birth against the recommendations of her physician for cesarean delivery ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Buetow</Author><Year>1998</Year><RecNum>1216</RecNum><record><rec-number>1216</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Buetow, S.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Four strategies for negotiated care</title><secondary-title>Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine</full-title></periodical><pages>199-201</pages><volume>91</volume><dates><year>1998</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[12][12].

Current models of the patient-physician relationship preclude consideration of the equal interests of patients and physicians. These models disregard the moral right and responsibility of physicians and patients to care and be cared about, and the adverse effects of an exclusive focus on the interests of patients. Disagreement with the equal interests of patients and physicians is presumably a result of concern that this principle loses the spotlight on the patient. However, any such concern is mistaken. Consideration of equal interests makes the spotlight larger rather than smaller, illuminating and giving equal focus to the equal interests of patients and physicians so as to sharpen sight of both parties. Achieving this focus requires a new, more balanced and unified model of the patient‑physician relationship. Our model locates this focus in recognition that “to care is to coprovide” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Buetow</Author><Year>2005</Year><RecNum>2271</RecNum><record><rec-number>2271</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Buetow, S</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>To care is to coprovide</title><secondary-title>Ann Fam Med</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Ann Fam Med</full-title></periodical><pages>553-555</pages><volume>3</volume><dates><year>2005</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[2][2] for patients and physicians according to the capacity and power of each in individual circumstances. This concept of coprovision involves the ability to “see,” and be responsive to, interests of the “other” and “self.” Physicians need to care about the patient as other and about themselves. Patients have an interest in caring about themselves and the physician as other. Yet, the physician has to enable and encourage the patient to achieve these directions of sight on which basis the patient can share responsibility for coprovision.

The metaphor of the “window mirror” brings this model to life by showing how a balanced focus on self and other makes it possible to see both parties at the same time – and so alternate the focus. If we sit in a lit room and attempt to look out into the dark, the window acts as a mirror whereas a person outside in the dark can look through the window to view its illuminated interior. However, if the light on each side has the same intensity, the glass acts as a window and mirror (Using two partially transparent mirrors achieves the same effect).

The same principles apply to the patient‑physician relationship. There is a tendency to think of patients as being in a lit room, while physicians keep the light off. As a result, physicians view patients rather than themselves, and patients are helped to see themselves rather than their physician. Our model therefore emphasizes the need to shower both parties in light so that each can see the other and itself. While specifying a mechanism for increased responsiveness to physician interests, it prevents under‑recognition of patients’ legitimate needs; and cannot devalue patient interests without contravening what it means to care. It increases the transparency and directionality of the interaction process – allowing patients to “see out” and physicians to “see in” – so that they can meet their moral rights and responsibilities around mutuality in caring and achieve mutual betterment.

More specifically, the window mirror metaphor makes visible, at the same time, at least four directions of sight: physician to patient; patient to self; physician to self; and patient to physician. The first two directions are the best understood, so we will elaborate the last two.

Why, then, can and should patients care about their physicians, in support of the above moral imperatives?

Physicians are an appropriate focus for patients to care about because physicians and patient‑physician relationships are important to patients ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Magee</Author><Year>2003</Year><RecNum>2665</RecNum><record><rec-number>2665</rec-number><ref-type name="Conference Paper">47</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Magee, M</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Relationship-based health care in the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Germany, South Africa and Japan</title><secondary-title>World Medical Association 'Patient Safety in Care and Research'</secondary-title></titles><dates><year>2003</year><pub-dates><date>September 11, 2003</date></pub-dates></dates><urls><pdf-urls><url>http://www.wma.net/e/press/pdf/2003_15.pdf</url></pdf-urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[18][18]; and caring makes physicians important to patients ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Frankfurt</Author><Year>1982</Year><RecNum>2663</RecNum><record><rec-number>2663</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Frankfurt, H</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The importance of what we care about</title><secondary-title>Synthese</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Synthese</full-title></periodical><pages>257-72</pages><volume>53</volume><dates><year>1982</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[19][19]. In turn, physicians can benefit. For example, being cared about by patients is another source of extrinsic motivation on professional behavior in the midst of pay for performance.

Readers may counter that despite the potential benefits to both parties, seriously ill patients are too physically and emotionally vulnerable to care about physicians – problems exacerbated by asymmetries of information and power in the patient‑physician relationship. However, we have already explained that our model does not assume equality of capacity and power between patients and physicians; and we need not be too defensive. At least in non-acute situations, patients may promote their own health or attempt to restore it. Worrying about caregivers tempers the benefits noted above but it may be managed through interventions such as education to enhance communication and concordance.

Thus, our basic point stands: patients can care about physicians because care and caregiving are not merely phenomena “of a caregiver perfectly reflecting a patient’s needs but an interaction in which both caregiver and patient care about and for each other” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Hauser</Author><Year>2006</Year><RecNum>2745</RecNum><record><rec-number>2745</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Hauser, JM</author><author>Chang, C-H</author><author>Alpert, H</author><author>Baldwin, D</author><author>Emanuel, EJ</author><author>Emanuel, L</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Who's caring for whom? Third, some patients may believe that when patients reciprocate care, or are not free to reciprocate, the physician may exceed for them the ordinary duty of care owed to all patients. If physicians reward some patients only, this is controversial – although not necessarily inappropriate. For example, consider patients who persistently default on appointments without good reason, not caring about the implications for physicians or other staff. Penalties in this situation may be “consistent with justice if they are ‘deserved’ (merit‑based view) … or can fairly guide the allocation of scarce resources or have a reasonable chance of leading to desired patient outcomes (consequentialist view)” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Buetow</Author><Year>2007</Year><RecNum>2578</RecNum><record><rec-number>2578</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Buetow, S.A.</author><author>Elwyn, G.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Patient performance standards: the next bold policy initiative in health care? </title><secondary-title>Journal of Health Services Research and Policy </secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Journal of Health Services Research and Policy</full-title></periodical><pages>48-53</pages><volume>12</volume><dates><year>2007</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[26][26].

On the basis of these reasons, how might patients care about their physician? One answer is via self-care, and patients are morally obliged to be open, be honest, honor their commitments and disclose relevant information. Most patients can and do respond to cues, such as the use of pause or eye contact, that their physician is under pressure or needs more time or that the visit has come to an end. These patients know what is socially expected and many can imagine the pressures under which their physician works. Through showing respect and concern, some patients can go further. They can absolve physicians of the need to “rescue” them, not blame physicians for failure that takes place as and when illness progresses, be sensitive to physicians’ own grief and fears, and even “teach … human dimensions of care” that lead “to healing, for both the patient and the physician” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Branch</Author><Year>2001</Year><RecNum>2309</RecNum><record><rec-number>2309</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Branch, WT</author><author>Kern, D</author><author>Haidet, P</author><author>Weissmann, P</author><author>Gracey, CF</author><author>Mitchell, G</author><author>Inui, T</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Teaching the human dimensions of care in clinical settings</title><secondary-title>JAMA</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Journal of the American Medical Association</full-title><abbr-1>JAMA</abbr-1></periodical><pages>1067-1074</pages><volume>286</volume><number>9</number><dates><year>2001</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[27][27].

Physicians, as noted above, are prone to stress and burnout; and many of them neglect their own health. At least in family medicine, therefore, they have “not only a duty to care for patients but also a duty to care for themselves and their colleagues” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Royal New Zealand College of General Practitioners (RNZCGP)</Author><Year>2002</Year><RecNum>2746</RecNum><record><rec-number>2746</rec-number><ref-type name="Report">27</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Royal New Zealand College of General Practitioners (RNZCGP),</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Self-cae for General Practitioners. Information and review activities</title></titles><dates><year>2002</year></dates><pub-location>Wellington</pub-location><publisher>RNZCGP</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[28][28]. Yet, up to one‑third of physicians do not have a regular source of medical care ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Gross</Author><Year>2000</Year><RecNum>2696</RecNum><record><rec-number>2696</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Gross, CP</author><author>Mead,, LA</author><author>Ford, DE</author><author>Klag, MJ</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Physician, Heal Thyself?: Regular Source of Care and Use of Preventive Health Services Among Physicians.</title><secondary-title>Arch Int Med</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Arch Int Med</full-title></periodical><pages>3209-3214</pages><volume>160</volume><dates><year>2000</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[29][29]; and according to Avery ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Rogers</Author><Year>1998</Year><RecNum>2510</RecNum><record><rec-number>2510</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Rogers, T.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Barriers to the doctor as patient role. A cultural construct</title><secondary-title>Aust Fam Physician</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Aust Fam Physician</full-title></periodical><pages>1009-13</pages><volume>27</volume><number>11</number><dates><year>1998</year><pub-dates><date>Nov</date></pub-dates></dates><accession-num>9845992</accession-num><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[30][30], physician self‑care is characterized by 3Ds – delusion, denial and delay – and a 4S approach – “self‑investigation, self‑diagnosis, self‑treatment and self‑referral.”

One reason for physicians’ work stress is that “in the idealized professional relationship … physicians’ feelings are extraneous.” Physician altruism puts care for others before the care of oneself: “patients are intended to be the sole focus of the relationship” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Meier</Author><Year>2001</Year><RecNum>2509</RecNum><record><rec-number>2509</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Meier, DE</author><author>Black, AL</author><author>Morrison, RS</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The inner life of physicians and care of the seriously ill</title><secondary-title>JAMA</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Journal of the American Medical Association</full-title><abbr-1>JAMA</abbr-1></periodical><pages>3007-14</pages><volume>286</volume><dates><year>2001</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[31][31]. In this context, physician self‑interest has acquired a pejorative sense even though, according to Foucault ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite ExcludeAuth="1"><Year>1997</Year><RecNum>2664</RecNum><record><rec-number>2664</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Foucault, M. </author></authors><subsidiary-authors><author>Rainbow, P</author></subsidiary-authors></contributors><titles><title>Michael Foucault. Ethics. Essential works of Foucault 1954-84</title></titles><volume>1</volume><dates><year>1997</year></dates><pub-location>London</pub-location><publisher>Penguin Books</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[14][14], care of the self is required for “the proper practice of freedom in order to know oneself … form oneself” – and so be able to care about others. In addition, empathy among physicians can make them vulnerable to “compassion fatigue” ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Figley</Author><Year>1995</Year><RecNum>2505</RecNum><record><rec-number>2505</rec-number><ref-type name="Book">6</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Figley, CR.</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Compassion Fatigue</title></titles><dates><year>1995</year></dates><pub-location>New York</pub-location><publisher>Brunner/Mazel</publisher><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[10][10]; physicians’ personality profiles can contribute to burnout; and, according to game theory, physicians can try too hard, in repeated interactions with patients, to cooperate for future payoffs ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Tarrant</Author><Year>2004</Year><RecNum>2704</RecNum><record><rec-number>2704</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Tarrant, C</author><author>Stokes, T</author><author>Colman, AM</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Models of the medical consultation: opportunities and limitations of a game theory perspective</title><secondary-title>Qual Saf Health Care</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Quality & Safety in Health Care</full-title><abbr-1>Qual Saf Health Care</abbr-1></periodical><pages>461-6</pages><volume>13</volume><dates><year>2004</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[32][32]. In turn, loss of perceived control over health ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Gross</Author><Year>2000</Year><RecNum>2696</RecNum><record><rec-number>2696</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Gross, CP</author><author>Mead,, LA</author><author>Ford, DE</author><author>Klag, MJ</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Physician, Heal Thyself?: Regular Source of Care and Use of Preventive Health Services Among Physicians.</title><secondary-title>Arch Int Med</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Arch Int Med</full-title></periodical><pages>3209-3214</pages><volume>160</volume><dates><year>2000</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[29][29] and lack of self-awareness may best explain physicians’ decisions not to seek medical care for themselves ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Longhurst</Author><Year>1988</Year><RecNum>2736</RecNum><record><rec-number>2736</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Longhurst, M</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Physician self-awareness: the neglected insight</title><secondary-title>Can Med Assoc J</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Can Med Assoc J</full-title></periodical><pages>121-4</pages><volume>139</volume><dates><year>1988</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[33][33].

This neglect of work stresses and health needs can produce unintended effects. It can harm physicians’ health and be devastating for patients. However, it is because physician self-care can support physician well-being that physicians have been reminded to admit vulnerability and share their emotional lives with patients ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>McLeod</Author><Year>2003</Year><RecNum>2735</RecNum><record><rec-number>2735</rec-number><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>McLeod, ME</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The caring physician: a journey in self-exploration and self-care</title><secondary-title>Am J Gastroenterology</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Am J Gastroenterology</full-title></periodical><pages>2135-8</pages><volume>98</volume><dates><year>2003</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[34][34]. Association</full-title><abbr-1>JAMA</abbr-1></periodical><pages>3007-14</pages><volume>286</volume><dates><year>2001</year></dates><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote>[31][31].

The primacy of patient interests in current models of the patient‑physician relationship underscores an unmet need to care better about our physicians and, through logical extension, our patients. We acknowledge that physicians and patients do not have equal capacity and power to alternate the focus or the provision of care, and we do not wish to burden patients, who may be already vulnerable. However, patients and physicians are morally entitled – and, according to their capacity, are obliged – to care and be cared about. Reciprocation in caring can also be expected to benefit patients and physicians, more so than existing models with their singular, decontextualized focus on patients. Our metaphor of the window mirror describes how physicians and patients can fulfill these justifications for consideration of equal interests. It signifies a new, more egalitarian model whose implementation will require physicians to educate and empower patients to help meet agreed expectations for the coproduction of care as a mutual activity. Doing this can be expected to dignify the moral autonomy of patients and physicians, and co‑create an adult‑adult relationship conducive to improved and shared health care outcomes.
